Let $\alpha_i=\displaystyle \min_{k\neq i}\{\alpha_{ik}\}$ and $\beta_i=\displaystyle \min_{k\neq i}\{\beta_{ik}\}.$\\

The number common neighbours of the vertex $2\in \Gamma$ with all other vertices are 
$N(2,1)=2$, $N(2,3)=2$, $N(2,4)=3$, $N(2,5)=2$, $N(2,6)=3$ and $N(2,7)=3$. Note that the vertex $2$ is adjacent to all other vertices except the vertex $7$. Thus, we obtain 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\alpha_2&=&\min\{\frac{1}{4}+\frac{4}{5},\frac{1}{4}+\frac{6}{5},\frac{6}{5}\}\\
&=&1.05
\end{eqnarray*} and 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\beta_2&=&\min\{\frac{1}{4}+\frac{2}{5}+\frac{4}{5},\frac{1}{4}+\frac{2}{5}+\frac{6}{5},\frac{6}{5}\}\\
&=&1.2
\end{eqnarray*}
Similarly, for all other vertices of $\Gamma$ we estimate,
$\alpha_1=0.75$, $\beta_1=1.25$, $\alpha_3=0.75$, $\beta_3=1.25$, $\alpha_4=0.75$, $\beta_4=1$, $\alpha_5=0.333$, $\beta_5=0.833$, $\alpha_6=0.75$, $\beta_6=1$, $\alpha_7=0.25$, $\beta_7=0.917$.\\
 
Therefore, using theorem \ref{st:th5} we get,
